text:
Hello,

I'm using Apache with mod_ssl dynamically loaded 

I start Apache with these lines :
start() { 
        echo -n $"Starting $prog: "
        daemon $httpd -DSSL `moduleargs` $OPTIONS
        RETVAL=$?
        echo
        [ $RETVAL = 0 ] && touch /var/lock/subsys/httpd
        return $RETVAL
}

And I reload it with :
reload)
        echo -n $"Reloading $prog: "
        killproc $httpd -HUP
        RETVAL=$?
        echo
        ;;

My problem is the following : when I reload Apache, in fact, I restart it. I 
see it on the server-status page : all the processes are killed, and the uptime 
is set back to 0. It also makes all the current downloads fail, as a restart 
closes all the active connections. 

Is there any patch to apply, so that Apache+mod_ssl won't restart when I just 
reload it ?

Thanks for your help
creator: mc@webheberg.com
nd@perlig.de
text:
Hmm. If you call the restart process "reload" that doesn't change the reality.
The supported interface for controlling apache is the apachectl script, where
you have the options 'start', 'restart' and 'graceful'. That latter provides a
graceful restart, which holds the children until their connections are gone.

I'm wondering how do you get the impression, that there's any "reload" support
in apache.
Additionally mod_ssl for 1.3 is not maintained here, you should contact your
vendor (modssl.org?) for support regarding this.

Thanks for using Apache.

You are right, there is a "reload" section in my /etc/init.d/httpd, but it only 
does a restart in fact...

I knew the existence of "graceful restart" but was ignoring that it holds the 
children until their connections are gone. It's exactly what I need, and it 
works fine, thank you
